questions.text: What is the most common cause of septic arthritis in children?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Staphylococcus aureus

 

Option A)

 

  • Staphylococcus aureus is a gram-positive bacterium that is part of the normal flora of the skin and mucous membranes.

  • It is the most common causative organism of septic arthritis in children, especially in cases involving older children and adolescents.

  • It can lead to rapid joint destruction if not treated promptly.

  • It can enter joints through direct inoculation (e.g., trauma, surgery) or hematogenously (from another infected site in the body).

  • Septic arthritis caused by Staphylococcus aureus typically presents with fever, swelling, redness, and severe pain in the affected joint.

  • The knee is the most commonly involved joint.

  • Treatment generally involves drainage of the infected joint and antibiotic therapy, often including methicillin or other appropriate antibiotics, depending on susceptibility.

 

Other options:

 

Option B) Haemophilus influenzae: Haemophilus influenzae is a gram-negative bacterium that can cause a variety of infections, including respiratory tract infections and meningitis. This pathogen was once a common cause of septic arthritis in children, particularly those under 5 years of age, before the widespread use of the Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) vaccine. It typically spreads through respiratory droplets and can lead to systemic infections, including septic arthritis, in vulnerable populations. Septic arthritis caused by H. influenzae usually presents similarly to other causes, with fever and joint pain. While it is a potential cause, its prevalence has significantly decreased due to vaccination, making it less common than Staphylococcus aureus in current clinical practice.

 

Option C) Streptococcus pneumoniae: Streptococcus pneumoniae is a gram-positive bacterium known for causing pneumonia, meningitis, and otitis media. It can cause septic arthritis, particularly in children, but is not the most common causative agent. It is more associated with infections of the respiratory system and can spread to joints. Like H. influenzae, it spreads through respiratory droplets and can lead to systemic infections, including septic arthritis. The presentation of septic arthritis caused by S. pneumoniae is similar to that of other organisms, with joint pain and swelling. Although a possible cause of septic arthritis, it is less frequently encountered than Staphylococcus aureus in children.

 

Option D) Escherichia coli: Escherichia coli (E.coli) is a gram-negative bacterium commonly found in the intestines. Some strains can cause serious infections, including urinary tract infections and gastrointestinal disease. E. coli can cause septic arthritis, particularly in neonates and children with underlying conditions, such as urinary tract infections or abdominal infections, leading to hematogenous spread. It typically enters joints through the bloodstream or following trauma. It is more common in children with specific risk factors. Symptoms are similar to other causes of septic arthritis, including joint swelling, pain, and fever. While E. coli can cause septic arthritis, it is not the most prevalent organism responsible for this condition in children.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The most common cause of septic arthritis in children is Staphylococcus aureus.

  • While other pathogens like Haemophilus influenzae, Streptococcus pneumoniae, and Escherichia coli can also cause this condition, they are less frequently encountered compared to Staphylococcus aureus in current clinical settings.

  • The emergence of antibiotic-resistant strains and the impact of vaccination programs have influenced the epidemiology of these infections over time.

questions.text: Physaliphorous cell (Larger vacuolated cells) on histopathology are characteristic of:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chordoma

 

Option C)

 

  • Chordoma is a rare malignant bone tumor arising from notochordal remnants, most commonly found in the axial skeleton (sacrum, clivus).
  • The hallmark of chordoma is the presence of physaliphorous cells—large, vacuolated cells that resemble bubbles and are often surrounded by a myxoid stroma.
  • These cells produce mucin and are indicative of the tumor's origin from notochordal tissue.
  • Symptoms depend on the location of the tumor and may include pain, neurological deficits, and bowel or bladder dysfunction in sacral chordomas.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Osteosarcoma: Osteosarcoma is the most common primary malignant bone tumor, typically occurring in the metaphysis of long bones (especially around the knee). It is characterized by the presence of malignant osteoblasts and varying amounts of osteoid production. The cells are often pleomorphic and show high mitotic activity. Patients usually present with pain, swelling, and sometimes a pathological fracture. Radiologically, osteosarcomas may show a "sunburst" pattern or Codman's triangle.

 

Option B) Osteoclastoma: Osteoclastoma, or giant cell tumor of bone, is a benign but locally aggressive tumor that typically arises in the epiphysis of long bones, particularly around the knee. Characterized by the presence of numerous giant cells (multinucleated osteoclast-like cells) and mononuclear stromal cells. The tumor may also have a background of reactive bone and fibrous tissue. Patients often present with joint pain and swelling, particularly in young adults (20-40 years old). X-rays typically show a lytic, subarticular lesion.

 

Option D) Chondrosarcoma: Chondrosarcoma is a malignant tumor that produces cartilage and is the second most common primary malignant bone tumor, commonly found in the pelvis and long bones. Composed of chondrocytes producing a cartilage matrix. Depending on the grade, it may show varying degrees of cellularity, atypia, and calcification. Patients typically present with pain and swelling. Radiologically, it appears as a lytic lesion with calcified areas.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Chordoma is characterized by physaliphorous cells, indicating its origin from notochordal remnants.

questions.text: What is the primary goal of orthopaedic rehabilitation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Functional improvement

 

Option B)

 

  • Functional improvement is focused on restoring a patient's ability to perform daily activities and participate in their usual lifestyle.

  • This may include enhancing mobility, balance, and coordination, enabling the individual to return to work, sports, or leisure activities.

  • This is generally considered the primary goal of orthopedic rehabilitation.

  • The ultimate aim is to improve the patient's quality of life by enabling them to function effectively and independently.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Pain Management: Pain management is a crucial aspect of rehabilitation. It involves various strategies to reduce pain through medications, physical therapy modalities (like heat, cold, and electrical stimulation), and psychological support. While important, pain management is typically considered a means to an end rather than the primary goal. Reducing pain can facilitate engagement in rehabilitation activities but does not encompass the full scope of rehabilitation's objectives.

 

Option C) Strength Gain: Strength gain involves exercises and activities designed to increase muscle power and endurance. This can be a significant component of rehabilitation, especially following surgery or injury. While strengthening is vital for recovery and overall function, it is typically a subset of the broader objective of functional improvement. Gaining strength contributes to functional abilities but is not the sole focus.

 

Option D) Range of Motion Improvement: Improving range of motion (ROM) involves exercises and interventions aimed at increasing joint mobility. This is essential for regaining function, particularly after injuries or surgeries that may limit movement. Like strength gain, improving ROM is crucial but is considered one aspect of the overall goal of functional improvement. Enhanced range of motion supports functional tasks but is not the ultimate aim of rehabilitation.

 

Educational objective: 

 

  • Functional improvement captures the overarching objective of orthopaedic rehabilitation, which is to enhance the patient's ability to engage in daily activities and improve their quality of life.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy presents with growth on talus as seen on foot x-ray. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Osteochondroma

 

  • Osteochondroma is a common benign bone tumor that typically presents as a growth on the bone with a cartilage cap. 
  • In this case, the boy has a growth on the talus, which is characteristic of osteochondroma.
  • X-ray Findings: On x-ray, osteochondroma appears as a bone growth projecting from the surface, often with a cartilaginous cap that is not visible on the x-ray itself since cartilage is radiolucent.
  • Presentation: Patients often notice a palpable mass, which feels larger than what is seen on the x-ray due to the cartilage component (as radiolucent).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Enchondroma: This is a benign cartilaginous tumor that occurs inside the bone (endosteal). It is more common in small bones of the hands and feet and does not present as an external growth.

 

 

Option B. Osteosarcoma: This is a malignant bone tumor typically found in the metaphyses of long bones, such as around the knee. It presents as a destructive bone lesion with a periosteal reaction, often not seen in the talus.

 

 

Option C. Osteomyelitis: This is an infection of the bone that leads to inflammation. It usually shows a solid periosteal reaction or lytic cavities on x-ray and does not present as a growth. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given x-ray image shows growth in the talus which is characteristic of osteochondroma of the talus bone. 
  • Osteochondroma is a benign bone tumor presenting as a palpable growth with a cartilaginous cap, most often found in young adults, and visible on x-ray as a bony projection.

questions.text: Which HLA is associated with Reiter’s syndrome? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) HLA B27

 

REACTIVE ARTHRITIS

 

  • Reactive arthritis (ReA) is inflammatory arthritis that manifests after several days to weeks after a gastrointestinal or genitourinary infection.
  • It is also described as a classic triad of arthritis, urethritis, and conjunctivitis. However, a majority of patients do not present with the classic triad.
  • It is known to be triggered by a bacterial infection, particularly of the genitourinary (Chlamydia trachomatis, Neisseria gonorrhea, Mycoplasma hominis, and Ureaplasma urealyticum) or gastrointestinal (GI) tract (Salmonella enteritidis, Shigella flexneri, and S. disenteriae, Yersinia enterocolitica, Campylobacter jejuni, Clostridium difficile).
  • The incidence is about 2-4% after a urogenital infection, mainly with Chlamydia trachomatis, and varies from 0-15% after gastrointestinal infections with Salmonella, Shigella, Campylobacter, or Yersinia.
  • Pathophysiology:
    • Reactive arthritis is an immune-mediated syndrome triggered by a recent infection.
    • It is hypothesized that T lymphocytes are induced by bacterial fragments such as lipopolysaccharide and nucleic acids when invasive bacteria reach the systemic circulation.
    • These activated cytotoxic-T cells attack the synovium and other self-antigens through molecular mimicry.
    • It is believed that anti-bacterial cytokine response is also impaired in reactive arthritis, resulting in decreased bacteria elimination.
    • The prevalence of HLA-B27 in reactive arthritis is estimated at 30-50% in patients with reactive arthritis.
    • HLA-B27 should not be used as a diagnostic tool for diagnosing acute ReA.
    • The presence of HLA-B27 is believed to potentiate reactive arthritis by presenting bacterial antigens to T cells, altering the self-tolerance of the host immune system, increasing tumor necrosis factor-alpha production, promoting the invasion of microbes in the gut, and delaying clearance of causative organisms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option. B. HLA DR3: This allele is more commonly associated with other autoimmune conditions, such as type 1 diabetes and systemic lupus erythematosus, rather than with reactive arthritis.

 

Option. C. HLA DR4: This allele is most notably associated with rheumatoid arthritis, especially in individuals who have severe disease forms.

 

Option. D. HLA DQ8: This HLA subtype is also more commonly associated with type 1 diabetes and not typically linked with reactive arthritis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • HLA-B27 is strongly associated with reactive arthritis (Reiter's syndrome) and other spondyloarthropathies like ankylosing spondylitis, psoriatic arthritis, and enteropathic arthritis.
  • Approximately 75-80% of patients with reactive arthritis test positive for HLA-B27.
  • But it should not be used as a diagnostic tool for acute ReA.

questions.text: A 15-year-old male presents with the following x-ray of knee. It is suggestive of: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Osteosarcoma

 

  • The given image shows the Codman’s triangle which is a characteristic radiological finding in osteosarcoma. 
  • Codman's triangle is a periosteal reaction, seen on X-ray, characterized by the lifting of the periosteum with a triangular piece of dense calcification underneath. 
  • This appearance is indicative of an aggressive periosteal reaction. 
  • It is commonly associated with malignant lesions or chronic processes, with osteosarcoma being a typical example.
  • Sun Ray Appearance is another X-ray finding where there are multiple radiating spicules extending from a bone, resembling rays of the sun. 

 

Note - While these periosteal reactions are highly suggestive of certain bone conditions, they are not diagnostic on their own. The definitive diagnosis of bone lesions, whether benign or malignant, is confirmed through a tissue biopsy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ewing’s Sarcoma: Ewing's sarcoma can show aggressive periosteal reactions such as an onion peel appearance.

 

 

Option C. Osteochondroma: This is a benign bone growth that typically have a distinct appearance with an exostosis pointing away from the joint.

 

 

Option D. Osteomyelitis: This condition can show a periosteal reaction, but it is usually a solid, narrow zone reaction and not the wide zone reaction like Codman's triangle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Codman's triangle on an X-ray is a suggestive sign of osteosarcoma, a malignant bone tumor.

questions.text: Congenital Zika virus infection shows microcephaly with gray matter-white matter zone calcification. The investigation of choice to detect congenital Zika virus infection is:
questions.solution:
Ans. D. NCCT

 

Option D.

 

Non-Contrast Computed Tomography (NCCT) is ideal for detecting calcifications due to its high sensitivity for variations in tissue density.


NCCT is the best investigation to detect calcification.

 

The thumb rules for NCCT are as follows:

 

  • IOC for head, spine trauma
  • IOC for acute SAH
  • IOC for intracranial calcification
  • IOC for renal calculi
  • IOC FOR IOFB
  • IOC for bone cortex
  • Initial Investigation in stroke

 

 

Calcifications seen in different infections

Cytomegalovirus – Periventricular infection

Zika virus – calcification at Grey matter-White matter junction

Toxoplasmosis – Intraparenchymal calcification

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. MRI. Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) is highly sensitive for soft tissue contrast and brain structure anomalies but less sensitive for calcifications.

 

Option B. X-Ray. Standard X-ray imaging can detect large calcifications but lacks the sensitivity and specificity of cross-sectional imaging for detailed brain assessment.

 

Option C. CT Angiography. CT angiography is used primarily to visualize blood vessels and is not the investigation of choice for detecting brain calcifications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Non-Contrast Computed Tomography (NCCT) is the preferred diagnostic tool for identifying intracranial calcifications associated with congenital Zika virus infection, offering clear delineation of calcified structures within the brain.

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition (2018),page 802

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient suffered a fall from the 2nd floor. A burst fracture of L2 is suspected. What will be the investigation of choice?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. NCCT

 

Option C.

 

NCCT is ideal for acute spine trauma, providing detailed images of bone fractures and the spinal canal.

 

NCCT is the imaging modality of choice for evaluating traumatic spine injuries. It can quickly and accurately diagnose the presence and extent of bony injuries, such as burst fractures, which are common in high-energy trauma. NCCT also allows for the evaluation of the spinal canal and neural foramina, which can help in assessing potential neurological complications.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. USG (Ultrasonography). USG is not suitable for spinal injuries due to its poor penetration through bone.

 

Option B. MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging). While MRI excellently delineates soft tissue and spinal cord injuries, it's not typically the initial test for acute bony trauma.

 

Option D. X-RAY. While X-rays can reveal some fractures, they may not provide the necessary detail to assess the full extent of a burst fracture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

NCCT is the preferred initial imaging study for a suspected burst fracture due to its rapid, detailed visualization of bony injuries and the spinal canal, essential in the setting of high-energy trauma.

 

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition (2018), page 834

choices.text: Contrast-enhanced CT
Diffusion-weighted MRI
Non-contrast CT

questions.text: A 23-year-old man was brought to the casualty with a head injury following an RTA. What is the investigation of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
Answer: D) Non-contrast CT

 

Non-contrast CT is the investigation of choice to identify acute intracranial bleeding and hence, is the preliminary investigation in acute head injury.

choices.text: Silver nitrate
Silver carbonate
Silver sulfate

questions.text: Which is the most common active ingredient used in conventional X-ray film?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Silver bromide

 

Option D.

 

The conventional method of screen-film radiography involves the use of X-ray film coated with a photosensitive emulsion containing silver bromide and silver iodide on both sides.

 

  • In mammography, only one side of the film is coated.
  • X-ray films exhibit the highest sensitivity to blue light and the lowest sensitivity to red light, which is why a red safe light is used in the darkroom.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common active ingredient in conventional X-ray film is Silver Bromide, used in the photosensitive emulsion coating on both sides of the film, with mammography film typically coated on one side, and this composition is highly sensitive to blue light while being least sensitive to red light.

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition (2018), page 222

choices.text: When electron beam reacts with the electromagnetic field
When electron beam strikes the cathode
When electron beam decelerates close to the nucleus of the atom in the anode
When electron beam strikes the nucleus of the atom in the anode

questions.text: Which process accurately describes the production of X-rays in an X-ray tube?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. When electron beam decelerates close to the nucleus of the atom in the anode

 

Option C.

 

X-rays are generated by the deceleration of an electron beam near the nucleus of the atom in the anode.

 

 

 

When electrons interact with the atoms of the anode, which can happen in two ways: -

 

  1. A fast-moving electron can interact with the atomic nucleus, resulting in continuous spectrum radiation, also known as Bremsstrahlung reaction (80%)

or

  1. It can interact with an inner shell of an atom, producing characteristic spectrum radiation (20%).

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

X-rays are primarily generated when an electron beam decelerates near the atomic nucleus within the anode, producing Bremsstrahlung radiation.

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition (2018), page 222

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with severe heel pain, especially with the first steps in the morning. On examination, there is tenderness at the plantar fascia insertion. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Plantar fasciitis

 

Option A)

 

  • Plantar fasciitis is an inflammatory condition of the plantar fascia, a thick band of tissue that runs across the bottom of the foot and connects the heel bone to the toes.
  • Symptoms:
  • Sharp heel pain, particularly with the first steps in the morning or after prolonged periods of sitting.
  • Pain may decrease with activity but can return after prolonged standing or walking.
  • Tenderness at the medial aspect of the heel, where the plantar fascia attaches to the heel bone.
  • Clinical diagnosis is made based on history and physical examination.
  • Imaging (such as ultrasound or MRI) is usually not required unless there is suspicion of a more serious condition.

 

Other options:

 

Option B) Achilles Tendinitis: Achilles tendinitis involves inflammation of the Achilles tendon, which connects the calf muscles to the heel bone. Symptoms include pain along the back of the heel, particularly during activities like running or jumping, stiffness and swelling around the tendon, especially in the morning. Pain may improve with activity but worsen with excessive use. Clinical examination reveals tenderness along the tendon and possibly thickening of the tendon. Imaging may help rule out tears or degeneration.

 

Option C) Tarsal Tunnel Syndrome: Tarsal tunnel syndrome is a compression neuropathy of the posterior tibial nerve as it passes through the tarsal tunnel. Symptoms include pain, numbness, or tingling in the sole of the foot, particularly around the arch and heel. Symptoms may worsen with activity and improve with rest. Pain is often described as a burning sensation. Physical examination may show symptoms along the course of the nerve, and Tinel’s sign may be positive. Nerve conduction studies can confirm the diagnosis.

 

Option D) Heel Spur: A heel spur is a bony growth (osteophyte) on the underside of the heel bone (calcaneus) that can develop in response to chronic plantar fasciitis. Symptoms include heel pain that may be associated with plantar fasciitis. However, heel spurs themselves can be asymptomatic and often do not cause pain unless associated with inflammation. X-rays may reveal the presence of a heel spur, but they are often found incidentally in patients with plantar fasciitis.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The given symptoms of heel pain on keeping the first step in the morning and tenderness on the insertion of the plantar fascia is characteristic of plantar fasciitis.
  • Plantar fasciitis is common and often responds well to conservative treatment measures such as stretching exercises, orthotics, and anti-inflammatory medications.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most convenient method for treatment of fracture shaft femur in children less than 2 years of age?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Spica

 

  • A spica cast is a type of cast that immobilizes the hip and thigh and is used to treat fractures of the femur in young children. 
  • The cast typically extends from the chest down to the foot or knee, depending on the location of the fracture.
  • In children under 2 years of age, spica casting is the treatment of choice for femoral shaft fractures. 
  • It is non-invasive, does not require surgery, and provides sufficient immobilization for the bone to heal. 
  • This method is effective, convenient, and associated with fewer complications compared to other methods.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Open Reduction and Internal Fixation (ORIF): This is a surgical technique where the fractured bone fragments are realigned and then stabilized internally using plates, screws, or rods. Typically indicated for complex or unstable fractures, particularly in older children or adults. In children under 2 years, ORIF is usually avoided due to the potential for complications, such as growth disturbances and the risks associated with surgery. This method is more invasive and requires careful management of post-operative care. Generally, not considered convenient or appropriate for this age group unless absolutely necessary due to its invasive nature.

 

Option C. Gallows traction: Gallows traction involves placing weights on a pulley system to apply a longitudinal force to the leg, pulling the femur into alignment. This traction is typically used in the treatment of fractures of the femur in infants and young children. While gallows traction is effective in certain circumstances (especially in very young children), it is not as commonly used today for femoral shaft fractures as spica casting. It is more cumbersome and requires prolonged hospitalization and monitoring, making it less convenient than spica casting.

 

Option D. External Fixation: This method uses external devices attached to the bone via pins or screws to stabilize a fracture. Typically reserved for more complex fractures or in cases where internal fixation is not feasible. While effective in certain situations, it is less commonly used for simple femoral shaft fractures in very young children. It carries risks such as pin site infections and complications associated with having external hardware. Not the first choice for simple femoral shaft fractures in children under 2 years due to its invasive nature and associated risks.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Spica Casting is the most appropriate, non-invasive, and convenient method of treatment. 
  • It provides sufficient immobilization and allows the bone to heal effectively with minimal risk of complications.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with sudden onset of severe pain in his big toe, along with redness and swelling. He has a history of hyperuricemia. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gout

 

Option B)

 

  • Gout is an inflammatory arthritis caused by the deposition of monosodium urate crystals in joints and periarticular tissues, with recurrent attacks of acute synovitis due to elevated levels of uric acid in the blood (hyperuricemia).
  • Commoner in men than in women (may be 20:1)
  • Symptoms:
  • Sudden, severe pain in a joint, most commonly the first metatarsophalangeal (MTP) joint (big toe).
  • Redness, swelling, and warmth in the affected joint.

 

 

 

  • Often described as excruciating, with the pain worsening at night or with minor movements.
  • Tophi (nodular deposits of monosodium urate monohydrate crystals) gets deposited in minute clumps in connective tissues.
  • Tophi may ulcerate through skin or destroy cartilage and periarticular bone
  • Attacks can be triggered by factors like alcohol consumption, certain foods (high in purines), stress, or dehydration.
  • Joint fluid analysis can reveal needle-shaped urate crystals under polarized light microscopy, confirming the diagnosis.
  • Elevated serum uric acid levels may be noted, though they can be normal during an acute attack.
  • X-rays may show chronic changes such as tophi (urate deposits) in advanced cases but are not diagnostic in acute settings.

 

 

  • During acute attack, X-rays show only soft tissue swelling.
  • Chronic gout may result in joint space narrowing and secondary OA.
  • Tophi appear as characteristic punched out cysts or deep erosions with over hanging bony edges (Martel’s or G’ sign).
  • These well-defined erosions are larger and slightly further from joint margin than typical RA erosions.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Osteoarthritis: Osteoarthritis (OA) is a degenerative joint disease resulting from the wear and tear of cartilage and underlying bone, often associated with aging or repetitive joint use. Symptoms include pain that is worse with activity and improves with rest, stiffness that lasts for < 30 minutes, commonly occurring in the morning or after periods of inactivity. Involvement of weight-bearing joints (e.g., hips, knees) and often the distal interphalangeal joints of the fingers. It typically does not present with acute swelling and redness. X-rays show joint space narrowing, subchondral sclerosis, osteophyte formation, and sometimes bone cysts. The diagnosis is primarily clinical based on history and physical examination findings.

 

 

Option C) Pseudogout: Pseudogout, or calcium pyrophosphate dihydrate (CPPD) crystal deposition disease, is characterized by the accumulation of calcium pyrophosphate crystals in the joint. Symptoms include sudden onset of joint pain and swelling, often affecting the knees but can involve other joints, including the big toe.

 

 

Symptoms can mimic gout but may be less intense and can occur in multiple joints. Joint fluid analysis shows rhomboid-shaped calcium pyrophosphate crystals under polarized light microscopy.

 

 

X-rays may show chondrocalcinosis (calcification of cartilage) but may not show significant findings in the acute phase.

 

 

 

Option D) Septic Arthritis: Septic arthritis is an infection within a joint, typically bacterial, and can occur after trauma or in patients with pre-existing joint disease. Symptoms include sudden, severe joint pain with swelling, redness, and warmth. Systemic symptoms may include fever, chills, and malaise. Patients often exhibit significant limitation in range of motion due to pain. Joint fluid analysis shows a high white blood cell count, often with a predominance of neutrophils, and cultures may reveal the infecting organism. Imaging (such as ultrasound or MRI) may be used to assess the joint for effusion or abscess.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Gout often requires prompt management to alleviate pain and prevent further episodes, typically involving NSAIDs, colchicine, or corticosteroids. Long-term management includes lifestyle modifications and medications to lower uric acid levels if hyperuricemia persists.

questions.text: Supracondylar fracture of the femur commonly injures which of the following structure?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Popliteal Vessel

 

Option C)

 

  • The popliteal artery and vein run through the popliteal fossa behind the knee.
  • The popliteal artery is a continuation of the femoral artery and is crucial for supplying blood to the lower leg and foot.
  • Supracondylar fractures can lead to direct injury to the popliteal vessels, either through fracture fragments or from swelling and hematoma formation.
  • Vascular injury is one of the most serious complications in such fractures.
  • Injury to the popliteal artery can lead to ischemia of the lower leg, presenting as pale, cold extremities, delayed capillary refill, and possibly necrosis of tissues if blood supply is compromised.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Sciatic Nerve: The sciatic nerve is the largest nerve in the body, originating from the lower lumbar and sacral plexus. It runs down the posterior aspect of the thigh and branches into the tibial and common peroneal nerves. While the sciatic nerve can be injured in fractures of the femur, it is typically more associated with proximal femoral fractures (like intertrochanteric fractures) rather than supracondylar fractures. Its anatomical location makes it less vulnerable in the case of a supracondylar fracture. Damage to the sciatic nerve can lead to motor and sensory deficits in the posterior thigh and lower leg, resulting in weakness of knee flexion and foot drop.

 

Option B) Popliteal Nerve: The popliteal nerve is a continuation of the sciatic nerve that travels down the posterior aspect of the knee and innervates the muscles in the back of the leg and parts of the knee joint. The popliteal nerve can be injured in supracondylar femur fractures, especially if there is significant displacement or swelling in the area. The nerve's position makes it susceptible to direct trauma or compression from hematoma formation. Injury to the popliteal nerve can result in weakness in plantar flexion and toe flexion, as well as sensory loss in the posterior leg and sole of the foot.

 

Option D) Femoral Vessel: The femoral artery and vein run in the groin area and down the thigh, providing blood supply to the upper leg. They are positioned more medially than the popliteal vessels. While femoral vessel injuries can occur with proximal femoral fractures, they are less commonly associated with supracondylar fractures of the femur due to the location of the fracture and the relative protection provided by surrounding structures. Injury to the femoral vessels can cause significant bleeding and swelling in the thigh and groin area, leading to a hematoma or potentially life-threatening hemorrhage.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • While the popliteal nerve can also be injured, the risk of vascular injury, particularly to the popliteal artery and vein, is a significant concern due to the fracture's location and the potential for complications such as ischemia.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with hip pain and a limp after running long distances. Physical examination reveals a positive Trendelenburg sign. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gluteus medius weakness

 

Option A)

 

  • The gluteus medius muscle is located on the lateral aspect of the hip, and it is primarily responsible for hip abduction and stabilization of the pelvis during activities such as walking or running.
  • Weakness in the gluteus medius can arise from several factors, including overuse, prior injury, or muscle imbalances.
  • Running long distances can exacerbate underlying weakness or tightness in this muscle.
  • Patients with hip abductor weakness typically present with hip pain, a limp, and a positive Trendelenburg sign.
  • The Trendelenburg sign indicates that the pelvis drops on the contralateral side when standing on the affected leg, reflecting the inability of the gluteus medius to stabilize the pelvis.

 

 

 

  • Diagnosis is made through physical examination, assessing strength and stability of the hip.
  • A positive Trendelenburg sign strongly supports hip abductor weakness, particularly in a patient with a history of increased physical activity.

 

Other options:

 

Option B) Femoral Neck Fracture: A femoral neck fracture commonly occurs in older adults or due to significant trauma. These fractures typically result from falls or high-impact injuries but can also occur with repetitive stress in some cases (e.g., in athletes with certain risk factors). Symptoms include hip pain, inability to bear weight, and a shortened and externally rotated limb. Patients may have severe pain with movement. Diagnosis is usually confirmed via X-ray or MRI. Given that this patient can run and does not present with significant acute trauma or inability to bear weight, a femoral neck fracture is less likely.

 

Option C) Avascular Necrosis: Avascular necrosis (AVN) refers to the death of bone tissue due to a lack of blood supply, commonly affecting the femoral head. AVN can occur due to trauma, corticosteroid use, excessive alcohol consumption, or certain medical conditions. Patients typically present with groin pain, which may radiate to the thigh or buttocks, and pain that worsens with weight-bearing activities. There may be gradual onset of pain rather than acute. Diagnosis is made via imaging (X-ray, MRI) showing characteristic changes in the femoral head. While AVN can lead to limping and pain, it does not directly cause a positive Trendelenburg sign.

 

Option D) Labral Tear: A labral tear refers to a tear in the cartilage surrounding the hip joint (the acetabular labrum), which can occur due to trauma, hip dysplasia, or repetitive stress. Labral tears are often associated with activities that involve twisting or pivoting motions, such as running or playing sports. Symptoms include hip pain, a feeling of instability, clicking or locking sensations in the joint, and pain that can radiate to the groin. Limping may occur, but it is not always present. Diagnosis is typically made through MRI or arthroscopy. Although a labral tear can lead to pain and some limping, it does not specifically cause a positive Trendelenburg sign due to gluteus medius weakness.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Hip Abductor Weakness (Gluteus Medius) aligns with the physical examination findings and the history of increased running activity, indicating weakness in the muscle responsible for stabilizing the pelvis during weight-bearing activities.
  • The trendelenberg sign is positive in case of gluteus medius weakness.

choices.text: Median nerve injury
Radial nerve injury
Ulnar nerve injury

questions.text: Knuckle-Bender splint is used for:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ulnar nerve injury

 

Option C.

 

KNUCKLE BENDER SPLINT

 

  • A Knuckle Bender Splint is an extension assist splint to bring mobility to the interphalangeal joints.
  • It is used for ulnar nerve palsy or to assist weak intrinsic muscles.
  • Provides dynamic MP flexion. 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Median nerve injury. In median nerve injury, wrist splint is more commonly used. Knuckle bender can also be used, but not commonly than a wrist splint.

 

Option B. Radial nerve injury. For radial nerve injury, a cock-up splint is used.

 

 

Option D. Erb’s palsy. In brachial plexus injury, aeroplane splint is used.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The knuckle bender splint is used commonly for ulnar nerve injury more than median nerve injury.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient presents with a 2-month history of severe pain in his right foot. Physical examination reveals a limited range of motion and a positive Thompson's test. Radiographs show the following. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Calcaneal fracture

 

Option A)

 

  • A calcaneal fracture typically results from high-energy trauma, such as falls from height or motor vehicle accidents.
  • They can also occur from less severe falls in patients with osteoporosis.
  • Patients often present with severe heel pain, swelling, and difficulty bearing weight.
  • A positive Thompson's test indicates possible involvement of the Achilles tendon, although it may not be directly related to the calcaneal fracture itself.
  • The limited range of motion is due to pain and swelling.
  • Diagnosis is confirmed with radiographs showing the fracture pattern and any potential displacement.
  • CT scans may be used for more detailed evaluation, particularly in surgical planning.

 

Other options:

 

Option B) Talus Fracture: A talus fracture usually results from high-impact injuries, such as falls or car accidents. They can also occur from ankle sprains. Symptoms include pain in the ankle, difficulty with ankle movement, and swelling. Limited range of motion can occur, but the pain is typically more localized to the ankle rather than the heel. Radiographs may reveal fractures of the talus, which can be difficult to visualize, and CT scans may be necessary for a clear assessment. The clinical presentation does not correlate with a calcaneal fracture.

 

Option C) Cuboid Fracture: A cuboid fracture can occur from direct trauma, such as a fall or ankle sprain, and are often associated with other injuries (e.g., foot fractures). Symptoms include lateral foot pain, swelling, and difficulty bearing weight. However, pain is usually localized to the midfoot rather than the heel, and a positive Thompson's test would not typically be associated with this type of fracture. Diagnosis is made through radiographs that may show displacement or comminution of the cuboid bone. The specific symptoms and examination findings do not align with this diagnosis.

 

Option D) Navicular Fracture: A navicular fracture often occur in athletes due to stress or acute trauma, such as an ankle sprain or direct impact. Symptoms include midfoot pain, swelling, and difficulty with weight-bearing. Pain is localized to the top of the foot, not the heel, and a positive Thompson's test would not be relevant. Radiographs or CT scans are used to identify fractures of the navicular. The symptoms described do not correspond with a navicular fracture.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Calcaneal Fracture aligns with the clinical presentation and imaging findings, indicating a significant injury to the heel bone.

choices.text: Polycystic kidney
Duplicated collecting system

questions.text: The following IVP is associated with:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Duplicated collecting system

 

Option B:

 

The drooping lily sign is a urographic sign in patients with a duplicated collecting system. It refers to the inferolateral displacement of the opacified lower pole moiety due to an obstructed (un-opacified) upper pole moiety. Wiegert-Meyer rule is followed for the duplex collecting system. Upper pole moiety is associated with obstruction and ureterocele with an ectopic bladder insertion. Vesicoureteral reflux is common in lower pole moiety.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Polycystic Kidney: On intravenous urography, "Swiss cheese nephrogram" or “Spider leg appearance”

 

Option C. Chronic Pyelonephritis: calyceal distortion

 

Option D. Hypernephroma/RCC: Soft tissue shadow of mass

 

Educational objective:

 

The drooping lily sign is a urographic sign in patients with a duplicated collecting system.

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 478

choices.text: Putty kidney
Staghorn calculus

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presenting with sterile pyuria. Radiograph is shown identify the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Putty kidney

 

Option B:

 

A putty kidney refers to a pattern of renal calcification associated with renal tuberculosis conventionally described on plain radiography. The calcification is characteristically very homogeneous and ground glass-like, representing calcified caseous tissue.

 

Putty kidney: The term describes the renal parenchyma's transformation into a putty-like mass due to chronic infection, typically renal tuberculosis. The calcification is homogenous and dense, giving a ground glass-like appearance on radiography, consistent with the image provided.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Nephrocalcinosis: It is characterized by the deposition of calcium salts in the renal parenchyma. The calcification is usually diffuse and involves the cortex and medulla. It's often associated with hypercalcemic conditions, but the patient does not present with a ground-glass appearance on radiography.

 

Option C. Staghorn calculus: This refers to a large renal calculus that conforms to the shape of the renal pelvis and calyces, resembling the antlers of a stag. It typically causes a branched radiopaque pattern on radiography, which is not demonstrated in the image provided.

 

Option D. Psoas Calcification: This is usually secondary to chronic processes such as infection or hematoma, resulting in calcification within the psoas muscle. It would appear along the course of the psoas muscle and not within the kidney.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The radiographic characteristics of a putty kidney, are homogenous, ground glass-like calcification, typically associated with renal tuberculosis.

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 418

choices.text: Multiple osteochondromas: multiple hereditary exostoses
Multiple enchondromas: Maffucci syndrome
Multiple enchondromas: Ollier syndrome
Multiple FD: McCune Albright syndrome

questions.text: Identify the diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Multiple enchondromas: Maffucci syndrome

 

Option B:

 

Multiple enchondromas: Maffucci syndrome - Maffucci syndrome is a rare disorder characterized by multiple enchondromas—benign cartilaginous growths within the bones—and soft tissue hemangiomas. This diagnosis is supported by the radiographic findings which show multiple enchondromas in the hands along with phleboliths, indicative of hemangiomas.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Multiple osteochondromas: multiple hereditary exostoses - Multiple hereditary exostoses are characterized by the presence of numerous osteochondromas, which are bony protrusions capped by cartilage. These typically arise on the external surface of bones, especially long bones, and are not usually seen within the short tubular bones of the hands as shown in the image.

 

Option C. Multiple enchondromas: Ollier syndrome - Ollier disease is a nonhereditary skeletal disorder characterized by multiple enchondromas confined to one side of the body, predominantly affecting the limbs. Unlike Maffucci syndrome, Ollier disease does not involve soft tissue hemangiomas.

 

Option D. Multiple FD: McCune Albright syndrome - McCune-Albright syndrome is characterized by fibrous dysplasia (FD), café-au-lait spots, and endocrine abnormalities. Fibrous dysplasia causes abnormal fibrous growths in place of normal bone, which is not what the radiographs show.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The radiographs demonstrate multiple enchondromas along with phleboliths in the soft tissues, findings that are indicative of Maffucci syndrome. This syndrome is characterized by the presence of both enchondromas and soft tissue hemangiomas.

 

Ref: Grainger &amp; Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 552

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the clinic with a complaint of difficulty swallowing for the past few months. He reports feeling as if food is getting stuck in his chest and he has to drink liquids to help it go down. He also reports regurgitation of undigested food and occasional chest pain. He denies any weight loss, heartburn, or reflux symptoms. On examination, his vital signs are within normal limits, and he appears well-nourished. Auscultation of the lungs is clear, and there are no abdominal masses or hepatosplenomegaly. A barium swallow study is ordered, as shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Achalasia cardia 

 

Option C:

 

Achalasia cardia typically presents with a dilated esophagus and a narrowed gastroesophageal junction creating a "bird-beak" sign, as seen in the image.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Diffuse esophageal spasm would show a corkscrew appearance on imaging, not seen here.

 

Option B: A hiatus hernia would show a protrusion of the stomach through the diaphragm into the thorax.

 

Option D: Carcinoma of the esophagus usually shows as an irregular narrowing or a stricture, commonly with a "rat-tail" appearance, which is not apparent in this image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The barium swallow study demonstrates a "bird-beak" sign, indicating achalasia cardia, a condition characterized by the failure of the lower esophageal sphincter to relax and the absence of normal esophageal peristalsis

 

 

Ref: Page no-248, Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition (2018)

choices.text: An abscess in the psoas muscle

questions.text: A 75-year-old male patient came to ER with the complaint of severe abdominal pain. CTA was performed which is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. A ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm

 

Option B:

 

The CTA shows a soft tissue density with contrast visible outside of the left side of the abdominal aorta. This is a result of extra luminal contrast being expelled from a ruptured aortic aneurysm.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. A ruptured gastric ulcer: A ruptured gastric ulcer typically presents with sudden onset of severe upper abdominal pain that may radiate to the back. On imaging, especially CT, we might see evidence of perforation with free air under the diaphragm (pneumoperitoneum). This finding is not consistent with the provided CTA image.

 

Option C. Acute appendicitis: Patients with acute appendicitis typically present with abdominal pain that begins around the navel and later localizes to the lower right abdomen, accompanied by fever and leukocytosis. A CTA would show an enlarged, inflamed appendix, potentially with an appendicolith (a calcified deposit), but no contrast extravasation outside the aorta as seen in the provided image.

 

Option D. An abscess in the psoas muscle: A psoas abscess would typically present with flank pain, fever, and a palpable mass, or difficulty with movements that involve the psoas muscle. On CTA, an abscess may appear as a well-defined fluid collection with possible enhancement after contrast administration. Again, this does not match the findings in the CTA image provided.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct diagnosis is B - A ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm. The provided CTA shows a soft tissue density with contrast visible outside of the left side of the abdominal aorta, indicative of extraluminal contrast from a ruptured aortic aneurysm. This is an urgent surgical emergency requiring immediate attention.

 

 

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 200.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to the breast clinic with a painless lump in her left breast that she discovered during a self-examination. On examination, a well-defined, mobile, firm, and non-tender mass of 2 cm is palpated in the upper outer quadrant of the left breast. The overlying skin is smooth, and there is no nipple discharge or lymphadenopathy. Mammogram is shown below. Classify the following mammography lesion as per BIRADS staging:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. BIRADS 2

 

Explanation:

 

This is a well-defined round mass accompanied with coarse popcorn calcifications, typical of an involuting fibroadenoma. As a result, it is categorized as a benign lesion (BIRADS 2).

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In mammography, a BIRADS 2 classification is assigned to findings that are clearly benign, such as a well-defined mass with characteristic 'popcorn' calcifications, typically seen in an involuting fibroadenoma.

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 682

questions.text: Diagnose the barium swallow as shown below
questions.solution:
Ans. A. B ring

 

Option A:

 

Schatzki ring is a symptomatic condition that occurs in the distal esophagus and is often associated with a hiatus hernia.

 

(B ring) refers to the Schatzki ring, a mucosal ring that occurs at the gastroesophageal junction and is associated with symptoms when tight enough to impede food passage. It's often associated with a sliding hiatal hernia.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: A ring refers to a mucosal or muscular structure above the B ring, which is typically asymptomatic and does not usually impede the passage of a barium swallow.

 

Option C: Esophageal web is a thin protrusion of tissue into the lumen of the esophagus, typically located in the upper esophagus and can be associated with conditions like Plummer-Vinson syndrome.

 

Option D: Esophageal stricture refers to a narrowing of the esophagus that can be caused by various factors such as chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), and would show a gradual tapering rather than a discrete ring.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The diagnosis is B ring, also known as Schatzki ring, which is a symptomatic mucosal ring located at the squamocolumnar junction, typically associated with a hiatal hernia.

 

 

Ref: Page no-238, Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition (2018)

questions.text: A 32-year-old male patient with a history of ulcerative colitis presents to the emergency department complaining of abdominal pain, distention, and fever. He reports having bloody diarrhea and has been using mesalamine and prednisone to manage his condition. On physical examination, his abdomen is tender and distended, and bowel sounds are absent. Laboratory tests indicate leukocytosis and electrolyte imbalances. An erect abdominal X-ray was taken as shown. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Toxic megacolon

 

Option D:

 

Dilated transverse and descending colon, with loss of characteristic haustrations is suggestive of toxic megacolon. The upper limit of normal bowel diameter for small bowel is 3 cm, for large bowel 6 cm and for cecum 9 cm.

 

The most widely used criteria for the clinical diagnosis of toxic megacolon are:

 

Radiographic evidence of colonic distension PLUS at least three of the following:

 

  • Fever > 38°C
  • Heart rate > 120/min
  • Neutrophilic leukocytosis >10,500/uL
  • Anemia

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Pneumatosis intestinalis involves the presence of gas cysts in the bowel wall, which is not indicated in this X-ray.

 

Option B: Perforation peritonitis would show free air under the diaphragm, which is not visible here.

 

Option C: Diverticulitis typically presents with localized colonic wall thickening and pericolic fat stranding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The characteristic radiographic findings of dilated colon segments and clinical symptoms suggest toxic megacolon, especially in a patient with a history of inflammatory bowel disease.

 

Ref: Page no-292, Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, 2nd Edition (2018)

choices.text: Chronic gastritis
Duodenal ulcer
Adenocarcinoma of stomach

questions.text: All of these pathologies occur due to H. Pylori infection of stomach except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Duodenal adenocarcinoma

 

Option D:


False. H. pylori infection is not typically associated with adenocarcinoma of the duodenum. While H. pylori is linked to gastric adenocarcinoma, duodenal adenocarcinoma is rare.

 

The correct answer is Option D: Duodenal adenocarcinoma. This condition is not commonly associated with H. pylori infection.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Chronic gastritis. True. H. pylori is a well-established cause of chronic gastritis. The bacteria's presence disrupts the gastric mucosal barrier and induces inflammation.

 

Option B: Duodenal ulcer. True. H. pylori infection is a major cause of duodenal ulcers. The bacteria increase gastric acid secretion and decrease bicarbonate production, leading to ulcers in the duodenum.

 

Option C: Adenocarcinoma of the stomach. True. Chronic infection with H. pylori, especially strains producing cytotoxins like CagA and VacA, is associated with an increased risk of gastric adenocarcinoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 Understanding the diseases associated with H. pylori infection is crucial for proper diagnosis and treatment. Chronic gastritis, peptic ulcers, and gastric adenocarcinoma are all conditions linked to this infection, but duodenal adenocarcinoma is not.

 

  • Infection with H. pylori leads to disruption of the gastric mucosal barrier by the enzymes produced by the organism, and the inflammation induced in the gastric epithelium is the basis of many of the associated disease processes.
  • The association of the organism with chronic (type B) gastritis is not in doubt.
  • Some strains of H. pylori produce cytotoxins, notably the Cag A and Vac A products.
  • Production of cytotoxins seems to be associated with the ability to cause gastritis, peptic ulceration and gastric cancer.

 

Ref: Bailey 28th Edition, page 1155.

choices.text: The Crow’s feet are spared distally
Has a relatively higher ulcer recurrence rate
Has the lowest post-operative mortality
A pyloroplasty is usually required for drainage

questions.text: A 40-year-old man has a history of severe epigastric pain and the pain was relieved after meals. Since treatment with PPIs turned out to be unsatisfactory, the following surgical procedure “C” was done. What is false regarding the procedure depicted here?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) A pyloroplasty is usually required for drainage

 

Option D:

 

The procedure “c” depicted in the picture is highly selective vagotomy. It is done for duodenal ulcers in order to reduce the acid secretion.

 

The principle of the operation is that the section of the Vagus nerves, which are critically involved in the secretion of gastric acid, reduces the maximal acid output by approximately 50%.

 

False. One of the benefits of HSV is that it does not typically require a concomitant drainage procedure like pyloroplasty because the pylorus function is preserved.

 

The correct answer is Option D: A pyloroplasty is usually required for drainage. This statement is false in the context of highly selective vagotomy.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: The Crow's feet are spared distally True. In HSV, the individual seromuscular branches of the anterior and posterior vagus nerves are divided, preserving the main trunks and the last 6-7 cm of the pyloric branches known as Crow's feet. This spares the pylorus and obviates the need for a drainage procedure.

 

Option B: Has a relatively higher ulcer recurrence rate True. Although HSV reduces the risk of ulcer recurrence compared to other surgical treatments, there is still a reported recurrence rate of 2-10%.

 

Option C: Has the lowest post-operative mortality True. HSV is associated with a low postoperative complication rate and has one of the lowest mortality rates among surgical procedures for peptic ulcer disease, at around 0.2%.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Highly selective vagotomy is a surgical procedure performed to treat peptic ulcer disease by selectively severing branches of the vagus nerve that innervate the acid-producing part of the stomach, sparing the pylorus and avoiding the need for additional drainage procedures like pyloroplasty. This procedure is characterized by a reduction of acid output, preservation of the Crow's feet, a moderate ulcer recurrence rate, and a low rate of postoperative complications and mortality, making it a well-tolerated treatment option.

 

HSV:

 

  • Individual branches of anterior and post Vagus are divided, preserving the main trunks as well as the last 6-7 cm of pyloric branches (Crow’s feet)
  • As pylorus is spared, a drainage procedure like pyloroplasty is not needed.
  • Acid reduction is moderate
  • High ulcer recurrence rate (2-10%)
  • Minimum postoperative complications (<5%) and lowest mortality (0.2%)
  • It is a BEST TOLERATED vagotomy procedure due to limited side effects

 

Other points regarding vagotomy:

 

  • Truncal vagotomy (cutting the vagal nerves at the lower esophagus) was the mainstay of treatment of duodenal ulceration
  • Because the vagal nerves are motor to the stomach, denervation of the antro-pyloro-duodenal segment results in gastric stasis in a substantial proportion of patients on whom truncal vagotomy alone is performed. The most popular drainage procedure was the Heineke-Mikulicz pyloroplasty.
  • Gastrojejunostomy is an alternative drainage procedure to pyloroplasty.
  • In highly selective vagotomy, only the parietal cell mass of the stomach is denervated.

 

Ref: Bailey 28th Ed. Fig 67.19, Page 1161

choices.text: Billroth- I reconstruction
Billroth II reconstruction
Braun anastomosis
Roux-en Y gastrojejunostomy

questions.text: What is the procedure being shown below?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Billroth II reconstruction

 

Option B:

 

Billroth II reconstruction This involves the removal of the lower part of the stomach and anastomosis of the remaining gastric stump to the jejunum. This is what is depicted in the image shown and is thus the correct answer.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. This is a procedure where the distal part of the stomach is removed, and the remaining portion of the stomach is directly connected to the duodenum. This option is not depicted in the image.

 

Option C: Braun anastomosis A modification of the Billroth II procedure, where a side-to-side anastomosis between the afferent and efferent loops of the jejunum is performed to reduce bile reflux into the stomach.

 

Option D: Roux-en-Y gastrojejunostomy In this procedure, the jejunum is divided, and the distal part is connected to the stomach to form the gastrojejunostomy, with the proximal end connected back to the jejunum further down to form a "Y" shape. This is not depicted in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Billroth II reconstruction is a surgical technique for gastric resection where the remaining portion of the stomach is anastomosed to the jejunum, usually in a retro-colic fashion, to re-establish gastrointestinal continuity following the removal of part of the stomach. This procedure is indicated for various conditions, including peptic ulcer disease and gastric cancer, and is depicted by the anastomosis of the greater curve of the stomach to the jejunum, bypassing the duodenum.

 

Billroth I gastrectomy: The lower half of the stomach is removed, and the cut end of the stomach is anastomosed to the first part of the duodenum.

 

Billroth II gastrectomy: Following resection, the distal end of the stomach is narrowed by the closure of the lesser curve aspect of the remnant. The greater curve aspect is then anastomosed to the jejunum.

 

Roux-en-Y gastrojejunostomy

 

 

Roux-en Y GJ: Jejunum is divided, distal jejunum is joined to stomach (Roux limb), proximal divided jejunum is joined to distal jejunum as shown in a Y configuration (image above).

 

Braun modification of classical Billroth II gastrectomy: Billroth II reconstruction with side to side jejunojejunostomy.

 

Braun’s anastomosis

 

 

Ref: Bailey 28th Ed. Pg 1160, 1163.

choices.text: Early dumping
Late dumping
Post vagotomy diarrhea

questions.text: Two months following Billroth 2 reconstruction done for peptic ulcer disease, patient complaints of lightheadedness, bloating and diarrhea 15 minutes after certain meals. He is suffering from?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Early dumping

 

Option A:

 

Occurs shortly after eating, usually within 15 to 30 minutes. It is caused by rapid emptying of the stomach contents into the small intestine, leading to symptoms like lightheadedness, abdominal fullness, nausea, diarrhea, and tachycardia. This matches the scenario described, where the patient experiences symptoms soon after meals.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Late dumping. Happens 1 to 3 hours after eating and is associated with hypoglycemia due to an exaggerated insulin response. Symptoms include weakness, sweating, and palpitations. It does not match the immediate post-meal timeframe mentioned.

 

Option C: Post vagotomy diarrhea This can occur after gastric surgery due to altered motility but typically does not cause lightheadedness or is related to meal timing.

 

Option D: G-J ulceration Gastrojejunal ulceration can cause symptoms like pain, but it is less likely to cause immediate postprandial symptoms like lightheadedness or diarrhea unless there is significant bleeding or obstruction, which is not described here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Early dumping syndrome is a complication that can occur after gastric surgery, such as a Billroth II reconstruction, and is characterized by symptoms of lightheadedness, tachycardia, diaphoresis, and diarrhea shortly after eating. These symptoms are due to the rapid transit of food into the small intestine, causing fluid shifts and autonomic reactions.

 

 

Ref: Bailey 28th Ed. Table 67.3

choices.text: Truncal vagotomy with pyloroplasty
Selective vagotomy with pyloroplasty
Highly selective Vagotomy
Truncal vagotomy with antrectomy

questions.text: Which of these procedures for peptic ulcers carries the lowest recurrence rate?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Truncal vagotomy with antrectomy

 

Option D:

 

This procedure involves cutting the main trunk of the vagus nerve and removing the lower part of the stomach (antrum), which contains cells that stimulate acid production. It has the lowest recurrence rate of approximately 1%.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Truncal vagotomy with pyloroplasty Involves cutting the main trunk of the vagus nerve to decrease acid secretion and a pyloroplasty to facilitate gastric emptying. Recurrence rates for ulcers can vary from 2 to 7%.

 

Option B: Selective vagotomy with pyloroplasty Selective vagotomy targets the nerves supplying the stomach only, sparing those to other abdominal organs like liver, combined with pyloroplasty. This has a slightly higher recurrence rate of 5 to 10%.

 

Option C: Highly selective Vagotomy (HSV) Also known as parietal cell vagotomy or proximal gastric vagotomy, HSV selectively denervates the acid-producing part of the stomach without a drainage procedure. Recurrence rates range from 2 to 10%.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the surgical management of peptic ulcers, truncal vagotomy with antrectomy is associated with the lowest recurrence rate of around 1%. However, it is important to balance this with the procedure's side effect profile, which can be poor compared to highly selective vagotomy, which has fewer side effects.

 

Recurrence rates after surgery for peptic ulcer:

 

  1. Truncal vagotomy with pyloroplasty - 2 to 7%
  2. Selective vagotomy with pyloroplasty - 5 to 10%
  3. Highly selective Vagotomy - 2 to 10%
  4. Truncal vagotomy with antrectomy - 1%

 

Though truncal vagotomy with antrectomy has the least recurrence rate, its side effect profile is poor (10 to 20%) compared to HSV <5%.

 

 

Ref: Bailey 28th Ed. Pg 1161.

questions.text: According to modified Johnson’s classification, hyperacid secretion is seen in which type of gastric ulcer?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2

 

Explanation:

 

Modified Johnson’s classification for location of peptic ulcers:

 

Type I - True gastric ulcers (lesser curve)

 

Type II - Combined gastric and duodenal ulcers - Hyperacid secretion

 

Type III - Supra-pyloric and pyloric ulcers - Hyperacid secretion

 

Type IV - Proximal ulcers (GE junction)

 

Type V - NSAID induced

 

 

Ref: Sabiston 21st Ed. Pg 1207.

choices.text: Allows visualization up to second part of duodenum (D2)
Can be used for variceal banding
Gold standard investigation for stomach disorders
Useful for diagnosing GIST

questions.text: What is the incorrect statement about this device?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Useful for diagnosing GIST

 

Option D:

 

The shown device is an upper GI endoscope/gastroscope. As GIST is usually submucosal, it may be missed on upper GI endoscopy.

The endoscope allows visualization of esophagus, stomach and proximal duodenum

 

This statement is false in the context given. While an upper GI endoscope can detect mucosal abnormalities, gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GISTs) are often submucosal, which may not be visible during a standard endoscopic exam. Endoscopic ultrasound or imaging studies may be more useful for diagnosing GISTs.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Allows visualization up to D2 This statement is true. An upper GI endoscope allows visualization of the esophagus, stomach, and proximal duodenum up to the second part (D2).

 

Option B: Can be used for variceal banding This is correct. The endoscope can be used to perform variceal banding, which is a treatment for esophageal varices.

 

Option C: Gold standard investigation for stomach. Endoscopy is indeed considered the gold standard for diagnosing many stomach conditions, such as peptic ulcers and gastritis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An upper GI endoscope is a versatile tool that allows visualization and intervention in the esophagus, stomach, and proximal duodenum. It is the gold standard for diagnosing mucosal diseases of the upper gastrointestinal tract and enables therapeutic procedures like variceal banding. However, it may not be sufficient for diagnosing submucosal lesions like GISTs, where additional imaging modalities may be required.

 

Ref: Bailey 28th Ed. Pg 1152.

choices.text: Man is the dead end host
PAIR is the treatment of choice in cysto-biliary communication
Echinococcus parasite is the causative agent

questions.text:
A 45-year-old male patient underwent a routine USG following which this finding was noted.

 

 

What is FALSE regarding the above condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) PAIR is the treatment of choice in cysto-biliary communication.

 

Option C.

 

PAIR (puncture aspiration injection re-aspiration) is the treatment of choice only in cases where the hydatid cysts have minimal septations and are superficial in location. Cysto-biliary communication is a contraindication for PAIR.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Man is the dead-end host, Option D: Echinococcus is causative. Echinococcus granulosus, the causative agent of hydatid disease, has a life cycle that involves dogs (definitive host) and sheep (intermediate host). Humans become accidental intermediate hosts by ingesting ova through contaminated food, water, or direct contact with dog feces. Once ingested, the eggs hatch in the intestines, and the larvae can migrate through the portal vein (PV) to various organs, most commonly the liver, where they form hydatid cysts. This is considered a dead-end in the parasite's life cycle because humans are not a part of the natural transmission cycle.

 

Option B: For conditions like echinococcus (hydatid) cysts, FNAC is contraindicated due to the risk of anaphylaxis and spread of infection

 

Educational Objective:

 

Echinococcus granulosus, a parasite with a life cycle involving dogs and sheep, causes hydatid disease in humans who are accidental hosts. PAIR treatment is contraindicated in cases of hydatid cysts with cysto-biliary communication due to the risk of biliary leak and cholangitis.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love 28th Ed. Pg 73-76

questions.text: The most common site for intestinal tuberculosis is?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Distal ileum

 

Option A:

 

The most common site of intestinal tuberculosis is the distal ileum and cecum.

 

This is correct. The distal ileum is the most common site for intestinal tuberculosis because it has an abundance of lymphoid tissue, which is conducive to the settlement and multiplication of Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Intestinal tuberculosis most commonly affects the ileocecal region and may present with a variety of symptoms including abdominal pain, weight loss, and fever. The disease can manifest in two forms, ulcerative and hyperplastic, with the ulcerative form often being secondary to pulmonary tuberculosis.

 

  • Ulcerative tuberculosis develops secondary to pulmonary tuberculosis and arises as a result of swallowing tubercle bacilli. Multiple ulcers, lying transversely, develop in the terminal ileum and the overlying serosa is thickened, reddened and covered in tubercles.

  • Hyperplastic is caused by the ingestion of Mycobacterium tuberculosis by patients with a high resistance to the organism. The infection usually occurs in the ileocecal region, although solitary and multiple lesions in the distal ileum are also sometimes seen.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love, 28th Ed. Pg 1308

questions.text:
A 26-year-old female patient present with attacks of abdominal pain and intermittent diarrhea. There is steatorrhea, anemia and loss of weight. Patient also has a mass in the right iliac fossa. A barium study shows the following:

 

 

What is your probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ileocecal TB

 

Option C:

 

The probable diagnosis for a patient presenting with abdominal pain, intermittent diarrhea, steatorrhea, anemia, weight loss, and a right iliac fossa mass, supported by a barium study showing a pulled-up cecum, is ileocecal tuberculosis (TB).

 

Ileocecal TB is the most likely diagnosis due to the combination of systemic symptoms, a palpable mass, and characteristic findings on imaging, such as the string sign of Kantor (narrowing of the terminal ileum), thickening, and gaping of the ileocecal valve, and thickening and hypermotility of the cecum).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Appendix carcinoid typically does not present with the systemic symptoms described or the specific radiologic findings seen in this barium study.

 

Option B: Amebic typhlitis may cause similar symptoms but would not typically result in the pulled-up cecum seen on the barium study.

 

Option D: Ulcerative colitis usually involves the colon and would not typically present with a pulled-up cecum, or the systemic symptoms described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ileocecal TB is characterized by systemic symptoms like weight loss and anemia, local findings such as a mass in the right iliac fossa, and specific radiologic signs in the barium study indicative of TB involvement in the ileocecal region.

 

  • Patients usually present with attacks of abdominal pain and intermittent diarrhea. There is incomplete ileal obstruction, leading to stasis and bacterial overgrowth. This in turn causes steatorrhea, anemia and loss of weight.

  • Patients may present with a mass in the right iliac fossa and vague ill health. The differential diagnosis is that of an appendix mass, lymphoma, carcinoma of the caecum, CD, tuberculosis or actinomycosis.

  • A barium follow-through or small bowel enema will show a long narrow filling defect in the terminal ileum (which may result in a differential diagnosis of CD). CT will also demonstrate the narrowed segment with proximal distension and the associated lymphadenopathy.

 

Barium study

 

1. Acute-to-subacute stage

 

  • Narrowing of the terminal ileum (string sign of Kantor)

  • Thickening and gaping of the ileocecal valve

  • Thickening and hypermotility of the caecum

 

2. Chronic stage

 

  • Ileo-cecal valve appears fixed, rigid and incompetent.

  • caecum appears conical in shape and shrunken in size.

  • Pulled-up caecum (away from the right iliac fossa) due to fibrotic changes in the mesocolon.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love 28th ed., pg 1308

Online article: https://doi.org/10.53347/rID-27606

choices.text: Diarrhoea is an early symptom
Perianal disease is characterized by multiple fistulae in ano
c-ASCA and fecal calprotectin are elevated

questions.text: All of these findings are common to both intestinal TB and Crohn’s disease, except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) C-ASCA and Fecal Calprotectin are elevated

 

Option D:

 

c-ASCA is an antibody elevated in Crohn's disease but not in TB. Fecal calprotectin is a marker of intestinal inflammation typically elevated in inflammatory bowel diseases like Crohn's disease. It is not commonly elevated in intestinal TB, as TB primarily involves infection with a specific pathogen rather than widespread inflammatory changes in the bowel.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Both intestinal tuberculosis (TB) and Crohn's disease can show granulomatous inflammation on biopsy, making this a common finding rather than an exception.

 

Option B: Diarrhea is often an early symptom in both conditions due to inflammation, ulceration and disruption of normal bowel function.

 

Option C: While perianal disease characterized by multiple fistulae in ano is more commonly associated with Crohn's disease, it may occasionally be seen in intestinal TB.

 

Educational Objective:

 

c-ASCA and fecal calprotectin is typically elevated in inflammatory bowel diseases like Crohn's disease and not in intestinal TB.

 

Similarities between Intestinal TB and Crohn’s:

 

  • Affect terminal ileum commonly

  • Characterized by ulcers

  • Granulomatous inflammation is seen

  • Can affect any part of GIT

  • Stricture, perforation and fistulation seen

  • Presentation is diarrhea or intestinal obstruction

  • Similar findings on contrast imaging: String sign, Sterlin sign

 

Ref: Bailey and Love, 28th Ed. Pg 1328-29

choices.text: Vitamin K injection
Resuscitation with PRBCs and FFP

questions.text: A 45-year-old male, who is a known case of cirrhosis of liver, presented to the casualty with painless profuse hematemesis. Which of these is not a component of his management?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Furosemide

 

Option D.

 

Hematemesis in a patient with cirrhosis is likely due to variceal bleed with portal hypertension.

 

Furosemide is a diuretic medication and is not typically used in the immediate management of profuse hematemesis. It's not a standard component of the treatment for this condition.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Vitamin K injection: Vitamin K is often given to patients with liver disease to help with clotting factors. 

 

Option B. Resuscitation with PRBCs and FFP (packed red blood cells and fresh frozen plasma): This is an essential component of management to replace blood loss and correct coagulopathy, which is common in cirrhosis-related bleeding.

 

Option C. Intravenous Octreotide: Octreotide is a medication used to reduce portal pressure by causing splanchnic vasoconstriction and can help control bleeding in cirrhotic patients with variceal bleeding. It's a critical part of the management.

 

So, the option that is not a component of the immediate management for a cirrhotic patient with painless profuse hematemesis is Furosemide (D).

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Patient should be admitted in ICU, two large-bore peripheral cannula and resuscitation commenced, ideally with blood. Liver function tests will reveal underlying liver disease and a coagulation profile will identify any coagulopathy. Hypervolemia may increase portal pressure and exacerbate bleeding.
  • Ten milligrams of vitamin K are administered intravenously while a coagulopathy requires FFP and activation of a major transfusion protocol. Thrombocytopenia secondary to hypersplenism is treated if the platelet count is less than 50,000.
  • Treatment protocols include the use of splanchnic vasoconstrictors, such as terlipressin, octreotide and somatostatin, and prophylactic antibiotics.
  • When bleeding continues treatment options are sclerotherapy, banding, balloon tamponade and TIPSS. The use of esophageal balloons should be avoided, which is usually possible when experienced endoscopists are available.
  • As soon as the patient is hemodynamically stable the diagnosis should be confirmed endoscopically as 30% will have a non-variceal source of bleeding. Variceal bleeding is often associated with hepatic encephalopathy and endotracheal intubation may be required prior to endoscopy to protect the airway and prevent aspiration.

 

Ref: Bailey 28th Ed. Pg 1204

choices.text: Banding has lower rebleed risk than sclerotherapy
All visible varices should be banded/sclerosed.
If patient has rebleed, another attempt at endoscopic management may be done.
Gastric varices are managed by cyanoacrylate glue injection.

questions.text: Which of these is incorrect regarding endoscopic management of variceal bleed?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. All visible varices should be banded/sclerosed.

 

Option B:

 

This is incorrect. Not all visible varices need to be banded or sclerosed during endoscopic management. Only the bleeding varices or those at significant risk of bleeding should be treated.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Banding has lower rebleed risk than sclerotherapy This is correct. Banding, or endoscopic variceal ligation, is preferred over sclerotherapy because it is associated with fewer complications and a lower risk of rebleeding.
