Option C: If a patient has a rebleed, another attempt at endoscopic management may be done This is correct. If a patient experiences rebleeding, a second attempt at endoscopic intervention can be made to control the hemorrhage.

 

Option D: Gastric varices are managed by cyanoacrylate glue injection This is correct. Injection of cyanoacrylate glue is an effective method for managing bleeding gastric varices.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the endoscopic management of variceal bleeding, not all visible varices should be treated; only the bleeding varices or those at high risk of bleeding are targeted for banding or sclerotherapy.

 

  • The two most commonly used endoscopic techniques are endoscopic band ligation to the base of the varix and injection of a sclerosant into or around the varix.
  • Following resuscitation, endoscopy is performed in a head-down position with good suction available. When the bleeding varix or varices are identified, only the source should be treated.
  • Sclerotherapy or banding both achieve effective control with banding reducing rebleeding; a single treatment is usually sufficient.

 

 

Ref: Bailey: 28th Ed. Pg 1204-05

choices.text: Most likely malignant
Symptoms are often due to release of catecholamines.
Somatostatin receptor scintigraphy is not very sensitive
Surgery of choice is enucleation

questions.text: All the following are true about insulinoma except?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Most likely malignant.

 

Option A:

 

More than 90% of insulinomas are benign and solitary. Tumours less than 2 cm in diameter without signs of invasion are considered benign.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Symptoms are often due to the release of catecholamines. This is correct. When insulinomas cause hypoglycemia, the body responds by releasing catecholamines, leading to symptoms such as sweating, weakness, hunger, tremors, nausea, anxiety, and palpitations.

 

Option C: Somatostatin receptor scintigraphy is not very sensitive. This statement is correct. Somatostatin receptor scintigraphy may not be very sensitive for detecting insulinomas, as these tumors may not always express somatostatin receptors in sufficient quantities to be detected by this imaging method.

 

Option D: Surgery of choice is enucleation. This is correct. The surgical treatment of choice for insulinomas, especially if they are benign and without signs of invasion, is enucleation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Insulinomas are most often benign, with clinical features including symptoms of neuroglycopenia and catecholamine release. The surgery of choice for localized, benign insulinomas is enucleation. Somatostatin receptor scintigraphy may not be sensitive for detecting insulinomas.

 

Clinical features-

 

  • Symptoms of neuroglycopenia which classically manifest while fasting or during exercise or sometimes post-prandially
  • Sweating, weakness, hunger, tremors, nausea, anxiety, palpitations all due to release of catecholamines.
  • Whipple’s triad-
  • Symptoms induced by fasting;
  • Hypoglycaemia at the time of symptoms;
  • Symptoms relieved by administration of glucose.

 

Investigations –

 

  • 72 hour fasting which will show symptoms along with elevated insulin and high C-peptide. If this test is negative and the suspicion of insulinoma is high, a prolonged oral glucose tolerance test is done.
  • After a positive fast test, a CT or MRI is performed.

 

Treatment–

 

  • Medical - diazoxide, somatostatin analogues
  • Surgical - enucleation

 

Ref: Bailey and Love’s Short Practice of Surgery 28th Edition Page 906

choices.text: pCO2 < 32 mm Hg
BP < 90/60 mm Hg
WBC count > 12000 / mm3

questions.text: Criteria for SIRS include all of the following except
questions.solution:
Ans. C) BP <90/60 mm Hg

 

Explanation:

 

Systemic Inflammatory Response Syndrome is defined by the presence of two or more of the following criteria:

 

  • Heart rate >90/min
  • Core temperature <36°C or >38°C
  • Respirations >20/min or PCO2 <32 mmHg
  • White blood cell count <4000 or >12 000/mm3

 

Ref: Bailey and Love’s Short Practice of Surgery 28th Edition Page 1271

choices.text: Non-cirrhotic portal fibrosis
Portal vein thrombosis
Budd Chiari syndrome

questions.text: Which of these is the most common cause of portal hypertension world-wide?
questions.solution:
Ans. A Cirrhosis

 

Explanation

 

Portal hypertension is most commonly due to liver cirrhosis, although it also occurs with extrahepatic portal vein occlusion, intrahepatic veno-occlusive disease and occlusion of the main hepatic veins (Budd–Chiari syndrome).

 

Ref: Bailey 28th ed. Pg 1203.

choices.text: Percutaneous gastrostomy

questions.text: Identify the feeding technique using this tube?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy

 

Option C:

 

Percutaneous gastrostomy - This method involves placing a feeding tube directly into the stomach through the abdominal wall. The tube in the image appears to be a percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) tube, which is characterized by an external fixation device to hold the tube in place against the abdominal wall.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Naso-gastric - This method involves the insertion of a feeding tube through the nose and down into the stomach. The tube in the image does not resemble a typical nasogastric tube, which is usually much longer and without the external fixation device.

 

Option B: Naso-jejunal - Naso-jejunal feeding also involves a tube that passes through the nose but goes beyond the stomach into the jejunum. This tube, like a nasogastric tube, is typically longer and would not have a fixation device as seen in the image.

 

Option D: Surgical gastrostomy - Surgical gastrostomy involves creating an opening into the stomach through a surgical procedure. While a PEG tube can be used for surgical gastrostomy, the method of insertion is different, and PEG specifically refers to the endoscopic technique.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The feeding technique using the tube shown in the image is most likely percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG), as indicated by the external bumper and the shorter length suitable for percutaneous insertion through the abdominal wall.

 

  • A PEG involves the insertion of the gastrostomy tube through the abdomen and stomach under vision via an endoscope, avoiding a surgical incision and a general anesthetic. The endoscopist is able to visualize a cannula entering the insufflated stomach via the anterior abdominal wall, through which a guidewire is passed.
  • Then either the gastrostomy tube can be inserted through the anterior abdominal wall over the guidewire or the guidewire can be pulled out via the mouth and the tube secured to the guidewire, pulled down into the stomach and then pulled out through the abdominal wall.
  • The stomach wall is pulled up to the anterior abdominal wall and held in place by a cuff, balloon or plastic bumper to minimise the risk of intraperitoneal leakage.

 

 

 

Ref: Bailey and Love, 28th Ed. Pg 336-337

choices.text: Re-feeding syndrome
Electrolyte disturbances

questions.text: All of these are complications related to tube feeds except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pneumothorax

 

Option D:

 

Pneumothorax - Pneumothorax is a complication associated with central venous catheter insertion, which may be performed for total parenteral nutrition (TPN) but is not a complication typically associated with enteral tube feeds.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Re-feeding syndrome - Re-feeding syndrome can occur when feeding is initiated in malnourished patients, leading to rapid shifts in electrolytes as insulin secretion is stimulated. This is a recognized complication of enteral feeding, though it is more common in TPN.

 

Option B: Diarrhoea - Diarrhoea is a common complication of enteral feeding, possibly due to the osmolality of the feed, contamination, or the rapid delivery of feed into the small intestine.

 

Option C: Electrolyte disturbances - Electrolyte disturbances can occur with enteral feeding, especially if the patient has underlying issues with fluid balance or if the feed composition does not match the patient's requirements.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While re-feeding syndrome, diarrhoea, and electrolyte disturbances are complications associated with enteral feeding, pneumothorax is not; it is instead related to central venous catheter insertion for total parenteral nutrition.

 

Complications of enteral feeding:

 

  1. Tube related
  • Malposition
  • Displacement
  • Blockage
  • Breakage/leakage
  1. Local complications (e.g., erosion of skin/mucosa)
  • Gastrointestinal
  • Diarrhoea
  • Bloating, nausea, vomiting
  • Abdominal cramps
  • Aspiration
  • Constipation
  1. Metabolic/biochemical 
  • Electrolyte disorders, including refeeding syndrome
  • Vitamin, mineral, trace element deficiencies
  • Drug interactions

 

Pneumothorax is related with central venous catheter insertion done for giving Total Para-enteral Nutrition (TPN).

 

Ref: Bailey and Love, 28th Ed. Box 25.3

choices.text: Femoral lines should be avoided for parenteral nutrition because of the high risk of infections.
In patients who are likely to require long-term parenteral nutrition, an implantable port or a Hickman line may be more appropriate.
The line is considered to be in the correct place if the tip is in the inferior third of the SVC or at the atriocaval junction.
Most common indication for TPN is acute pancreatitis.

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement about total para-enteral nutrition (TPN)?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Most common indication for TPN is acute pancreatitis.

 

Option D:

 

Most common indication for TPN is acute pancreatitis. - This statement is incorrect. The most common indication for TPN is not acute pancreatitis, but rather conditions that result in an inability to use the gastrointestinal tract for nutrition, such as short bowel syndrome or high-output intestinal fistulas. Acute pancreatitis may require TPN if enteral feeding is not possible, but it is not the most common indication.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Femoral lines should be avoided for parenteral nutrition because of the high risk of infections. - This statement is true. Femoral lines do carry a higher risk of infection and are generally avoided for TPN unless there are no other options.

 

Option B: In patients who are likely to require long-term parenteral nutrition, an implantable port or a Hickman line may be more appropriate. - This statement is also true. For long-term TPN, more permanent and less infection-prone access such as an implantable port or Hickman line is preferred.

 

Option C: The line is considered to be in the correct place if the tip is in the inferior third of the SVC or at the atriocaval junction. - This statement is true. The tip of the central line for TPN should ideally be located at the inferior third of the superior vena cava (SVC) or at the cavoatrial junction to ensure proper infusion and minimize risks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common indication for TPN is not acute pancreatitis, but conditions causing a significant reduction in the functional small bowel, often related to massive intestinal resection or fistulation. Proper line placement and avoiding high-infection-risk access points are crucial for the safe administration of TPN.

 

  • TPN is indicated in patients who are unable to meet their nutritional requirements via absorption of nutrients from their intestinal tract.
  • The commonest cause for this is in patients with short bowel syndrome related to massive intestinal resection or a significant reduction in functional small bowel, often related to intestinal fistulation.
  • Commonly provided by the hospital pharmacy in the form of a 3-litre bag containing a lipid emulsion with a mixture of essential and non-essential amino acids, glucose, electrolytes, trace elements and vitamins.
  • Usually administered directly into the central venous system (the superior vena cava [SVC] or the right atrium) to minimise the risk of venous thrombophlebitis, through either a peripherally inserted central catheter (PICC) or central venous catheter.
  • Femoral lines should be avoided for parenteral nutrition because of the high risk of infection.
  • In patients who are likely to require long-term parenteral nutrition, an implantable port or a Hickman line may be more appropriate. These are implanted via fluoroscopic or ultrasound guidance with a subcutaneous port or cuff and a catheter attachment sitting within the SVC.
  • Line misplacement can also occur and is diagnosed on chest radiograph, which is mandatory following central line insertion. The line is considered to be in the correct place if the tip is in the inferior third of the SVC or at the atriocaval junction.

 

 

Ref: Bailey and Love, 28th Ed. Pg 338-339

choices.text: Mets to brain

questions.text: A 70 years old male presents to OPD with severe cachexia and dysphagia to solids. Endoscopy shows lumen occluding growth at mid esophagus. While he is being investigated, you start him on TPN. After one day, patient gets seizures and tetany. What likely abnormality is responsible for the above event?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hypophosphatemia

 

Option C:

 

Hypophosphatemia - Hypophosphatemia is a known complication of refeeding syndrome, which can occur when nutrition is suddenly introduced to a malnourished patient. It can cause seizures, tetany, muscle weakness, and cardiac dysfunction, and is the most likely cause in this context.

 

The patient is suffering from refeeding syndrome typically seen after sudden institution of feeds in a chronically starved patient.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Mets to brain - While metastases to the brain can cause seizures, the acute onset of seizures and tetany after starting TPN suggests a metabolic cause rather than new brain metastases.

 

Option B: Hyponatremia - Hyponatremia can cause seizures due to an osmotic imbalance across the neuronal membrane, but it is not typically associated with the acute onset of tetany.

 

Option D: Hyperglycemia - Hyperglycemia can result from TPN due to the high glucose content in the solution; however, it is less likely to cause acute seizures and tetany compared to electrolyte disturbances like hypophosphatemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The sudden onset of seizures and tetany in a patient who has just started on TPN is most likely due to hypophosphatemia, a key feature of refeeding syndrome, which requires careful management and monitoring of electrolyte levels during the initiation of nutrition in malnourished patients.

 

  1. Refeeding syndrome: One of the most significant metabolic complications of both parenteral and enteral feeding is refeeding syndrome. This occurs in the first days after feeding is commenced in patients who have been severely malnourished. The degree of risk is related to their BMI, amount and rate of unintentional weight loss, period of starvation and electrolyte levels. The main underlying pathological process is one of hypophosphatemia, resulting in fluid and electrolyte shifts between the intra and extracellular compartments. Presentation includes arrythmias, muscle weakness, respiratory or cardiac failure, oedema, lethargy or seizures; and at its most severe, the syndrome can be fatal. Laboratory tests will reveal low levels of phosphate, potassium, calcium and magnesium and a lactic acidosis. Nutritional support in this group of patients should be started at a maximum of 10 kcal/kg per day, aiming to increase levels slowly to meet full needs by 4–7 days.
  2. Liver dysfunction: Long-term use of parenteral nutrition is associated with derangement of liver function tests in at least 25% of patients. Fatty liver is a common complication. This is worse in children, and the degree can be reduced by modifying the parenteral nutrition solution, such as alternating the use of lipid-free parenteral nutrition solutions. A smaller percentage of patients may subsequently develop liver fibrosis and cirrhosis.

 

 

Ref: Bailey and Love, 28th Ed. Pg 339-340.

questions.text: In carcinoma of the penis, which of these is not a premalignant condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Peyronie’s disease

 

  • Peyronie’s disease is characterised by penile plaques which leads to abnormal curvature of penis.
  • It is least likely to be premalignant from the given options.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A and B. Erythroplasia of Queret and Bowen’s disease: Are variants of penile intra-epithelial neoplasm and considered premalignant.
  • Option D. Leukoplakia: Is a premalignant condition of penis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Peyronie’s disease is an abnormal curvature due to penile plaques, managed by Nesbitt procedure.

choices.text: Medial Members of the Upper Horizontal Group of Superficial Inguinal Lymph Nodes
Lateral Members of the Upper Horizontal Group of Superficial Inguinal Lymph Nodes
Lower / Vertical Group of Superficial Inguinal Lymph Nodes

questions.text: A 54-year-old male 3 months ago started to feel a bulging lesion on the surface of glans penis.  known smoker for 20 years, no multiple sexual partners and no viral infection. Patient was circumcised. He started having difficulty in micturition. He went to the surgery OP. the glans penis was fully covered and invasion was detected in the urethral meatus. Biopsy was taken from the patient and the urethral meatus was opened. The biopsy result was squamous cell carcinoma. In the above condition which group of lymph nodes enlarge?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Deep Inguinal Lymph Nodes

 

Option D:

 

  • The lymphatics from glans penis drains into deep inguinal nodes. Hence in inflammation/malignancy of glans penis this group of nodes become enlarged

 

 

  • In cases of squamous cell carcinoma of the penis, the lymphatic drainage and potential sites of lymph node enlargement are crucial for understanding the spread of the cancer.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. These lymph nodes are part of the superficial inguinal group and are located just below the inguinal ligament. They receive lymphatic drainage from the penile and scrotal area. While these nodes can be involved in penile cancers, they are not typically the first group of nodes to show enlargement.

 

Option B. Similar to the medial members, these nodes are also part of the superficial inguinal group and can be involved in the lymphatic drainage of the penile region. They might be affected by metastasis in penile cancer, but they are generally not the primary or initial site of enlargement.

 

Option C. These nodes are also part of the superficial inguinal group and are located more medially and inferiorly compared to the upper horizontal group. They too receive drainage from the penile area and can be involved in the spread of penile cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The deep inguinal lymph nodes are a common site for the initial spread of penile cancers like squamous cell carcinoma. These nodes lie beneath the fascia lata and along the femoral vein. Given their anatomical location and lymphatic drainage patterns, they are often the first group of nodes to exhibit enlargement in the case of penile cancer.

 

 

Ref: Gray’s Anatomy 41st Edition Pg No 1320

choices.text: On doppler, “monophasic flow” implies normal flow
Rest pain is seen at ABPI < 0.5
0.1 decrease in ABPI leads 10% increase in mortality
Toe pressure is more reliable of ischemia in patients with diabetes

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement about peripheral vascular disease:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) On doppler, “monophasic flow” implies normal flow

 

In peripheral vascular disease (PVD), understanding Doppler findings and assessment measures is crucial:

 

  • On Doppler, “monophasic flow” implies normal flow: Incorrect. Normal arterial flow in the peripheral arteries is triphasic, indicating good vascular compliance and normal resistance. Monophasic flow is abnormal and indicates significant arterial disease with poor distal blood flow.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rest pain is seen at ABPI < 0.5: Correct. Rest pain in PVD patients typically occurs when the ankle-brachial pressure index (ABPI) is less than 0.5, indicating severe ischemia.

 

Option C. 0.1 decrease in ABPI leads to a 10% increase in mortality: Correct. A decrease in ABPI is associated with increased cardiovascular mortality risk.

 

Option D. Toe pressure is more reliable for detecting ischemia in patients with diabetes: Correct. In diabetic patients, calcification of the arteries can make ABPI measurements unreliable. Toe pressure or the toe-brachial pressure index is often more accurate in assessing the severity of ischemia in these patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Monophasic flow on Doppler is an indicator of significant arterial disease, not normal flow. Additionally, understand the importance of using toe pressure in diabetic patients for a more accurate assessment of ischemia, as ABPI can be unreliable due to calcified arteries.

 

ARTERIAL DOPPLER

 

  • Duplex scan= USG (B mode) + Doppler
  • Normal flow- Triphasic-> bi-> Mono-> absent
  • ABPI- <0.9 (occlusion), <0.5 (rest pain), <0.3 (CLI)
  • 0.1 fall in ABPI-> 10% increase in CV event
  • TBI < 0.6 in diabetes is more significant marker

questions.text: Which of these surgeries is performed for Meconium ileus?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bishop-Koop procedure

 

Option D:

 

Bishop-Koop Procedure: The correct choice for meconium ileus. This procedure creates a temporary diverting ileostomy with a distal anastomosis, allowing for the passage of meconium while bypassing the obstructed segment of the intestine.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Duhamel Surgery: This procedure is performed for Hirschsprung disease and involves a pull-through technique where the normal ganglionated colon is brought down to the rectum while preserving a portion of the aganglionic rectum.

 

Option B. Ramstedt Procedure: A surgical treatment for congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis, this procedure involves splitting the hypertrophied muscles of the pylorus to alleviate obstruction.

 

Option C. Kimura Surgery: This is a technique used for the correction of duodenal atresia, typically involving a duodenoduodenostomy to bypass the atretic segment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Bishop-Koop procedure is the surgical treatment for meconium ileus, involving a temporary ileostomy with a distal anastomosis to relieve intestinal obstruction caused by thickened meconium. However, it has been replaced currently by proximal enterotomy and removal of pellets. A trial of gastrograffin enema can be given prior to surgery to dissolve the pellets.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love’s short practice of surgery 28th edition pg 268, 1389
